did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: Papers, 1908-1985, bulk 1930-1980. This collection is comprised of Leland C. Wyman’s interests, both personal and professional. The bulk is made up of personal and professional correspondence, lecture note cards, and publications. His professional files reflect both his careers as a biologist and an anthropologist.

repository.corpname: University of Arizona Libraries, Special Collections

prefercite.head: Credit Line
prefercite.p: Leland C. Wyman papers(MS 441). Special Collections, University of Arizona Libraries.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Leland Clifton Wyman was born in 1897 Livermore Falls, Maine. He got his bachelor’s degree from Bowdoin College in 1918 and his Ph. D. degree from Harvard in 1922. He taught experimental and theoretical physiology, sociology, anthropology, American Indian art, and Asiatic art at the Boston College of Liberal Arts. He also directed research work on Navajo ethnology at the Department of Anthropology, University of New Mexico. From 1942 to 1946 he served as chairman of the Division of Medical Sciences at Boston University. He spent 40 summers conducting research in the American southwest establishing him as one of the leaders on Navajo research. He was an author of numerous publications in the fields of biology and anthropology. For various years he was the curator of archives at the Museum of Northern Arizona and research associate at the Museum of Navajo Ceremonial Art. As part of his research and personal interests he traveled to Asia, Africa, Middle East, and Europe. He died in 1988.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is organized into two series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This collection contains personal and professional materials relating to the life and career of Leland C. Wyman. The bulk of the personal series includes correspondence to and from Wyman as well as correspondence between others. General files relating to his personal life include his drawings and sketches and other materials collected by him including a song book, theatre programs, and newspaper clippings. Scrapbooks detail information on sports programs and materials on or about Livermore Falls and Bowdoin College. The professional series includes correspondence as well as general files on museum collections and his teaching files. The collection also contains a large amount of his index card lecture notes. Also present in the collection are numerous essays and publications by Leland Wyman, spanning over 60 years.
This subseries is arranged chronologically. It contains correspondence between Leland C. Wyman with his family and friends. It is organized alphabetically and chronologically.

This subseries is arranged alphabetically. It contains arts and crafts from childhood to his sketches for studying human anatomy, Bowdoin College files, calendars and schedules, childhood museum catalogue, essays, White Star ephemera, invitations and announcements, materials from his interest on magic and spiritual matters, newspaper clippings, notebooks, address book, song book, and theater programs from Europe.

scopecontent.p: This series is arranged alphabetically. It contains scrapbooks dedicated to Livermore Falls, Bowdoin College, and college sports.

scopecontent.p: This series is arranged chronologically and alphabetically. It contains the professional correspondence of Leland C. Wyman.

scopecontent.p: This series is arranged alphabetically. It contains Awards, recognitions, memberships, collection value, curriculum vitae, faculty and student evaluation, inventory of artifacts, invitations and announcements, journal, key to catalogue numbers of Wyman Collection, lectures and speaking engagements, miscellaneous, museum programs, flyers, catalogues, notes for exhibits, outlines, teaching materials, travel logs and itineraries.

did.unittitle: Key to catalogue numbers of Wyman Collection

scopecontent.p: This series is arranged alphabetically. It contains bibliography, essays, journal articles, newsletters, publications, and papers and publications by others.
Lecture note cards from his teaching days at Boston University on the topics of American Indians, Chinese, Japanese, and Indian culture and art.
